data.title: Double clicking terminal sash should position it in the ideal height, not minimum
Support CompletionItemKind.Method
data.body:
Previously, if a registered completion provider returned items with
`CompletionItemKind.Method`, they would display in the list as properties,
due to not being converted to the corresponding `SuggestionType`.

data.title: alt+click to add multiple cursors also toggles the menu bar
data.body:
In stable and Insider's build, on Windows.
1. Hide the menu bar (View > Toggle Menu Bar). You can press alt to toggle its visibility.
2. Hold alt and click to place a second cursor
3. When you release alt, the menu bar appears. You can press it again to hide it. But when alt is part of some other action, it shouldn't make the menu bar appear.

data.title: Media keys not working when vscode is the active window
data.body:
- **VSCode Version:** 1.4.0-insider
- **OS Version:** Windows 10 x64

**Steps to Reproduce:**

**1.** Use a keyboard that has macro support
**2.** Assign the media skip/back shortcut to one macro key

**What it should do:**
Change songs back and forth

**What it's currently doing:**
Nothing. Seems like `vscode` is capturing it, since it works everywhere else ...

Note: The "normal" media keys on the keyboard works properly, but not the macro I have.

data.body:

data.title: Ctrl+Shift+1 keybinding doesn't work to replace selected text when using Ctrl+H window
data.body:
- VSCode Version: Code 1.4.0 (6276dcb0ae497766056b4c09ea75be1d76a8b679, 2016-08-04T16:45:31.680Z)
- OS Version: Windows_NT ia32 10.0.10586

Steps to Reproduce:
1. Open/Create standard HTML File
2. Create the following input line: `<input type="text" name=variable1 size="10" value="">`
3. Press keybinding Ctrl+H to open find/replace window.
4. Enter RegEx string to Find:  `(\bname=\b)(([a-zA-z])+\b)`
5. Enter RegEx string to Replace: `$1"$2" id="$2"`
6. Press F3 to find first instance
7. Press Ctrl+Shift+1

We noticed the id tag was missing from some input variables so and also the quotations around the variable declared name so I created a RegEx expression to find and replace them.

RegEx for find window: `(\bname=\b)(([a-zA-z])+\b)`
RegEx for replace window: `$1"$2" id="$2"`

This finds any match on "name=anyword" where there are no quotes around the variable declared value and replaces it with `name="anyword" id="anyword"`

I was trying to speed up the process so I went to use the keybinding for Replace which when you hover above the Replace icon says the binding is "Ctrl+Shift+1".  When I press that key combination all at once or in sequential order, nothing happens.

data.title: Debug protocol: `setVariable` identifies variables by display name
data.body:
- VSCode Version: 1.4
- OS Version: All

The new `setVariable` request identifies variables by display name.  
This is fragile because the name may have been generated by the adapter (e.g. `[N]` for array indices). 
There may also be more than one variable with the same name in the stack frame in languages that allow variable shadowing.  For example, in C++ one can write 

``` c++
int a = 10; 
{ 
    int a = 20;
    ... // There are now two `a`'s here! 
```

The debugger can see both, even though in C++ there's no way to access the outer one.

To make this work robustly, I would suggest adding an optional "handle" field into `Variable`, which gets round-tripped back to the adapter in `setVariable`.

data.title: Add an action to move focus to Debug Console
data.body:
- VSCode Version: 1.4
- OS Version: All

There is no bindable action to quickly switch focus to the input line of the Debug Console.   Currently there are two actions that are close, but not quite as ergonomic as a dedicated one would be:
- There 's `workbench.debug.action.toggleRepl`, but it will toggle the console off if it's already open, so it needs to be done twice.
- There's also `editor.debug.action.selectionToRepl`, which will copy the current text selection into the Console and execute it.  However, if no text is selected, it does nothing.   (Can it be modified it to simply move focus to the Console in the latter case?)

data.title: Debug protocol: Please add Variable::settable
data.body:
- VSCode Version: 1.4
- OS Version: All

When a debug adapter reports that is supports setVariable, all leaf variables become editable, but compound objects do not.  While a reasonable heuristic, this is not optimal because:
- primitive values may be not editable if they are "synthetic" i.e. generated by a visualizer.
- compound objects may be editable, e.g. std::string (which may still want to show individual characters as children, and possibly provide a "raw" view of the implementation as a synthetic child).

I'd suggest adding an explicit "settable" flag into `Variable`.

data.title: Option to disable instead of completely uninstall a particular extension.
data.body:

I would like to be able to temporarily disable an extension without having to uninstall it entirely.

data.title: [debug] Variables with null values are not displayed.
data.body:
- VSCode Version: 1.4
- OS Version: All

When a debug adapter returns `Variable`s with `value: null`, they are not displayed in the variables viewlet.
However, this is a legitimate situation in some cases:
- For compound objects, there may not a useful information to return as a value of the container itself (Okay, this may be worked around by returning some canned string such as "<object>")
- Primitive types may also lack values if, e.g. one is debugging an optimized build.  Here, returning a canned string is more problematic, because VSCode will allow editing it and will try storing it back.

IMO, null-valued variables should still be displayed.

data.title: Pasting entire line does not replace selection
data.body:

Steps to Reproduce:
1. Create file with

```
line1
line2
```
1. Press `Cmd+C` while on first line
2. Select entire second line:
   ![image](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/1723815/17445743/32190f6c-5b14-11e6-913d-1cb35812961c.png)
3. Press `CMD+V` to paste

Instead of having 

```
line1
line1
```

we end up with:

For reference Atom produces:
![image](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/1723815/17445825/81f7372a-5b14-11e6-8425-d213b7cb8e70.png)

data.title: Option to run tasks.json from launch.json even if it doesn't define multiple tasks

milestone.title: Backlog
milestone.description: Work not yet planned for a specific release.

data.body:
launch.json offers the preLaunchTask field to run a specific task before debugging. This works great if I'm using Gulp or something else that supports multiple task names. However, if I set up a tasks.json that simply runs an executable, such as a compiler, there seems to be no easy way to run this singular task before launching. There is no task name, so I have nothing to pass to preLaunchTask. I'm forced to manually build with Ctrl+Shift+B before I launch.

It would be great if I could set it up so that my tasks.json would run automatically on launch. Maybe a new field, like the example below, where it runs whatever is associated with Ctrl+Shift+B:

```
{
    "preLaunchRunBuildTask": true
}
```

data.title: Can't copy the values of debugging elements such as exception messages
data.body:
_From @CarlosTorrecillas on August 5, 2016 8:24_
## Environment data

`dotnet --info` output:
.NET Command Line Tools (1.0.0-preview2-003121)

Product Information:
 Version:            1.0.0-preview2-003121
 Commit SHA-1 hash:  1e9d529bc5

Runtime Environment:
 OS Name:     Mac OS X
 OS Version:  10.11
 OS Platform: Darwin
 RID:         osx.10.11-x64

VS Code version: 1.3.1
C# Extension version: 1.3
## Steps to reproduce
- Create a .NET Console app
- Add the code to throw an exception
- On the debugging section try copy the value of either the message or the stacktrace
## Expected  behavior

## Actual behavior
- I get the message "error CS1012: Too many characters in character literal"

data.title: Please improve configuration of the debugger extensions
Open new untitled editors from double click at the end of the tab list
data.body:
**Issue:**
When double clicking in the empty tab space we open a new untitled buffer. However, if the active tab is not the last, this buffer opens not at the end of the list where you double clicked. The fix is to always open untitled buffers from double click at the end.

**Original:**
- VSCode Version: 1.5.0-insider 1a7ca5a Date 2016-08-05T07:19:53:669Z
- OS Version: Windows 10

-- Sorry for the English, I used Google Translator --

1º Situation

Steps to Reproduce:
1. Open two or more tabs that are not in Preview Editors.
2. Click on the first tab.
3. Open a new tab by double-clicking on the tab bar, or File> New File or Ctrl + N.

Note that the new tab and open the side of the first. I think it would be better to open in the last position equal to browsers.

2º Situation

Steps to Reproduce:
1. Open two or more tabs that are not in Preview Editors.
2. Click on the first tab.
3. Click on a file to open in Preview Editors.

This should open the side of the last tab and not the side that was previously opened.

data.title: Modification to the VS code startup batch file for #7619
data.body:
This as another attempt (previously #10162) at handling issue #7619 . This attempt handles situations involving  the `--wait` and `--verbose` arguments. In this revision the batch script will only use the `start` command when the arguments are empty. I have tested this by building and installing code-oss on my system and trying various scenarios:
- `code-oss` from a command prompt opens a new GUI window and does not block the command window it was launched from.
- `code-oss --wait` and `code-oss --verbose` block the command prompt while still opening the GUI window.
- Running `code-oss` from Windows 10 search (I had to enter the full path) launches the VS code GUI and only briefly flashes the console window.
- Running `code-oss --verbose` from Windows 10 search (I had to enter the full path) launches the VS code GUI and leaves a console open in the background with information written to it.
- I am not yet sure if `code-oss file.txt` works as my build is not complete but given that `CALL` would be used in that case I expect it to be fine.

data.title: `strictNullChecks: true` breaks imports of non-typescript modules.
data.body:
I posted this one to [StackOverflow](http://stackoverflow.com/questions/38778126/upgraded-to-tsc-2-0-0-node-modules-arent-resolved-by-vs-code-syntax-checker) already with a screenshot.

I am able to "solve" the problem by removing `strictNullChecks` from my `tsconfig.json`, although I really really want to use that feature.

Is this a bug? Misconfiguration on my end?

Thanks. Keep up the great work on VS Code.

data.title: Where is documentation for language configuration json?
data.body:
I can't find much info on the language json files. From playing around I've come up with the following:
- `comments.lineComment` is used for commenting out code via command
- `blockComment` unsure ??
- `brackets` will automatically cause indents if you press enter between a pair (surroundingPairs don't)
- `autoClosingPairs` obviously provides closing character automatically and can be excluded from strings and comments (not sure if there are any other options allowed here?)
- `surroundingPars` highlights the other part of the pair (but without adding the indent functionality that `brackets` get)

Is there a doc somewhere?

data.title: Can't use shift+home to select to beginning of line

milestone.title: Backlog
milestone.description: Work not yet planned for a specific release.

data.body:
- VSCode Version: 1.4.0
- OS Version: Windows 10 v1511 b10586.494

Steps to Reproduce: 
1. Open a file (I have tested this with .rb, .json, and .html files)
2. Click on the middle of a code line with indentation
3. Press <kbd>home</kbd> once & observe that the caret to the beginning of the text, after the indentation whitespace (**correct**)
4. Press <kbd>home</kbd> once more & observe that the caret moves to the beginning of the line, before the indentation whitespace (**correct**)
5. Press <kbd>home</kbd> once more & observe that the caret moves to the beginning of the text, after the indentation whitespace (**correct**)
6. Press <kbd>shift</kbd> + <kbd>home</kbd> & observe that nothing happens (**incorrect**). What should happen is that the caret should be at the beginning of the line with indentation whitespace selected.

It's possible there's a setting for this somewhere, but I didn't see it.
